triggers.name: ice_shards_status_tracker
triggers.commands: wait 2 set stage %actor.quest_stage[ice_shards]% if %stage% == 1 set book1 %actor.quest_variable[ice_shards:16209]% set book2 %actor.quest_variable[ice_shards:18505]% set book3 %actor.quest_variable[ice_shards:55003]% set book4 %actor.quest_variable[ice_shards:58415]% say You are looking for four books of mystic knowledge. if %book1% || %book2% || %book3% || %book4% mecho mecho You have brought me: if %book1% mecho - &3&b%get.obj_shortdesc[16209]%&0 endif if %book2% mecho - &3&b%get.obj_shortdesc[18505]%&0 endif if %book3% mecho - &3&b%get.obj_shortdesc[55003]%&0 endif if %book4% mecho - &3&b %get.obj_shortdesc[58415]%&0 endif endif mecho mecho You still need to find: if !%book1% mecho - &3&b%get.obj_shortdesc[16209]%&0 endif if !%book2% mecho - &3&b%get.obj_shortdesc[18505]%&0 endif if !%book3% mecho - &3&b%get.obj_shortdesc[55003]%&0 endif if !%book4% mecho - &3&b%get.obj_shortdesc[58415]%&0 endif elseif %stage% == 2 say I need you to find the Codex of War. elseif %stage% == 3 mecho %self.name% says, 'You are looking for any records or journals Commander mecho &0Thraja keeps.' elseif %stage% == 4 mecho %self.name% says, 'Talk to the pawnbroker in Anduin about the Butcher of mecho &0Anduin so you can find his map.' elseif %stage% == 5 mecho %self.name% says, 'Talk to Slevvirik in Ogakh about the Butcher of Anduin mecho &0so you can find his map.' elseif %stage% == 6 say Bring the map of Ickle from the Butcher of Anduin. elseif %stage% == 7 mecho %self.name% says, 'You are looking for any kind of written clues about the mecho &0library at Shiran in Ysgarran's Keep in Frost Valley.' elseif %stage% == 8 mecho %self.name% says, 'You are looking for the Book of Redemption, whatever mecho &0that is.' elseif %stage% == 9 mecho %self.name% says, 'You are looking for the lost library of Shiran in Frost mecho &0Valley!' elseif %stage% == 10 say Have you found the magic book in the lost library?? elseif %actor.has_completed[ice_shards]% mecho %self.name% says, 'You've already done a miraculous thing by bring the mecho &0Aqua Mundi to me! elseif !%stage% say Progress on what?  There's no fee to use the springs. smile %actor% endif

triggers.name: ice_shards_khysan_receive2
triggers.commands: set stage %actor.quest_stage[ice_shards]% if %stage% == 2 wait 2 quest advance ice_shards %actor.name% mjunk book emote cautiously takes %object.shortdesc% and places it on the reception desk. wait 2 say Yikes, this looks pretty dangerous. emote opens %object.shortdesc% and begins to read. wait 3s emote quietly continues to read. wait 2s say The Codex talks extensively about the wars fought in Frost Valley and the surrounding areas.  It says the Frost Elves have been here since long before people arrived in Technitzitlan. wait 1s say The Codex also says something catastrophic happened to the elves' majestic city Shiran "ages ago," though it doesn't say what or when exactly. wait 7s emote closes %object.shortdesc%. wait 3s say But the fact that the elves are still here must mean something, right? wait 3s say Frost Valley is one of the only places left in Caelia where elves are frequently spotted. wait 3s say They've been locked in combat with a group of Amazons just east of here.  Why, I don't know, but I do know they've been skirmishing for a long time. wait 4s say The commander of the ice warriors, Thraja, certainly knows more.  Go and see if she keeps any records or journals. wait 3s say Bring back anything you find and we can look over it together. endif

triggers.name: ice_shards_khysan_receive3
triggers.commands: set stage %actor.quest_stage[ice_shards]% if %stage% == 3 wait 2 quest advance ice_shards %actor.name% mjunk book emote sits down and reads through Commander Thraja's journal. wait 3s say There is quite a lot of detail about the Frost Elves and their general movements, but it doesn't look like Thraja ever figured out where they were coming from.  She also notes the elves don't seem to be invading so much as patrolling the area. wait 3s emote flips a few more pages. wait 3s say Thraja also notes maps of the region are unreliable as the terrain can subtly shift, almost like the valley is changing somehow. wait 3s say She says the best map she ever had of the region was a slightly magical one she received from Kara-Sithri but it was stolen by someone called "The Butcher of Anduin." wait 6s emote looks up from the journal. say Oh my, that's not a subtle name at all is it? wait 3s say Apparently some kind of serial killer, the Butcher may have wanted the map to expand his reign of terror into the region around Ickle.  Or he may have just been looking for some valuables to pawn near his hideout. wait 6s say Thraja hasn't seen the map since. wait 4s emote closes the journal. wait 3s say Well if this map really was some kind of ancient magical device, it might help us determine where Shiran was. wait 4s say I guess you could ask around the pawnshop in Anduin, see if you can figure out what the Butcher did with the map. endif

triggers.name: ice_shards_khysan_receive4
triggers.commands: set stage %actor.quest_stage[ice_shards]% if %stage% == 6 wait 2 quest advance ice_shards %actor.name% mjunk map say Incredible, you found it! emote excitedly lays out the map. wait 1s emote scours every tiny detail of the map. wait 3s say Let me compare... mecho emote opens to a passage in the Codex of War. emote glances between the Codex and the map. wait 4s say And in Thraja's journal... emote compares a passage in Thraja's journal. wait 3s say The Codex mentions a site of incredible significance in the middle of Frost Lake, and both the map and Thraja's journal point to the remains of a tower of some kind on an island in the lake. wait 6s say The map indicates the edges of a huge city that once overlooked the plateau at the west edge of the valley.  Thraja notes a man named Ysgarran built some kind of fortification over a preexisting structure out there... wait 7s say Go check it out.  Assuming that was Shiran, maybe there's a clue there?  Bring back anything you find, especially if you find any written records of the region. endif

triggers.name: ice_shards_khysan_receive5
triggers.commands: set stage %actor.quest_stage[ice_shards]% if %stage% == 7 wait 2 quest advance ice_shards %actor.name% mjunk book mecho %self.name% reads aloud, '"The Lost Library of Shiran".' say I... can't believe it's that obvious. wait 3s emote combs through the pages of the book. wait 4s say Okay, it's not that obvious. The book does talk about the library being destroyed for being a repository of too much mystical knowledge.  But it doesn't definitively say it was in Frost Valley. wait 6s say It does say the gods destroyed the library, claiming it was out of an abundance of caution, but was really an act of jealousy. wait 5s say What's even more interesting is what happened after!  A few of the gods repented and sought to atone for their crimes against Shiran.  They chronicled stories of good and evil as parables for what they had done and wrote those stories down into something called the "Book of Redemption." wait 7s say This book serves as the basis for a mystic path to salvation for wayward beings.  The writings themselves are so powerful they pose to drive the reader insane if they're unable to withstand the strain on their will. wait 6s say I hate to say it, but this sounds like a 'no stone unturned' situation.  If you can find a copy of this book, I'm willing to try to read it. endif

triggers.name: ice_shards_khysan_receive6
triggers.commands: set stage %actor.quest_stage[ice_shards]% if %stage% == 8 wait 2 quest advance ice_shards %actor.name% mecho Khysan carefully opens %object.shortdesc% and starts to read. wait 2s mecho &3&bLetters and images float up out of %object.shortdesc% and begin to dance around Khysan.&0 mjunk book wait 3s mecho Khysan's eyes glaze over and his jaw goes slack. zone wait 5s mecho Khysan shakes his head and snaps back into reality. wait 2s say Here's what it says: The gods were so afraid of the sheer amount of mystical knowledge in Shiran they tried to destroy it. wait 3s say Only it turns out, by then the library was so magically defended even the gods couldn't just obliterate it. wait 2s say So instead, they ripped open the time stream and tossed the library into it, causing the Time Cataclysm that destroyed Shiran and loosed the Time Elementals on Ethilien! wait 6s say But according to the book, the people trapped in the library were eventually able to create a sort of "time key".  They convinced a mighty Time Elemental Lord to bring it to our epoch where, in theory, it should still be!  By bringing the key to the ruins of the tower and somehow activating it, one can traverse between the ages!! wait 9s say WHAT?! bounce wait 2s say This is AMAZING!! wait 3s say Well, I guess that means there's one more place to go!  Find that key, travel into the past, find a copy of Ice Shards, and bring it back to the future! wait 2s salute %actor.name% say Good luck my friend! endif

triggers.name: ice_shards_khysan_receive7
triggers.commands: set stage %actor.quest_stage[ice_shards]% if %stage% == 10 wait 2 mjunk book hug %actor.name% say I don't know how I can ever express my gratitude to you for bringing this to me.  The Sunfire clan will be sure this knowledge is never lost again. wait 4s say Come, let's read this together. emote opens the book and flips forward a few pages. wait 3s emote points to a page. mecho say Here it is! wait 2s msend %actor% Although the spell is written in ancient Elvish, the intent and meaning are clear enough to replicate it! mecho quest complete ice_shards %actor.name% mskillset %actor.name% ice shards msend %actor% &6&bYou have learned Ice Shards!&0 endif

triggers.name: Khysan refuse
triggers.commands: switch %object.vnum% case %wandgem% case %wandtask3% case %wandtask4% case %wandvnum% halt break default set stage %actor.quest_stage[ice_shards]% switch %stage% case 1 switch %object.vnum% case 16209 case 18505 case 55003 case 58415 halt break default set response This isn't one of the four books I need to consult. done break case 2 if %object.vnum% != 55004 set response This isn't the Codex of War. endif break case 3 if %object.vnum% != 58806 set response This isn't Commander Thraja's journal... endif break case 6 if %object.vnum% != 48502 set response Weird, this doesn't look like a map of Ickle. endif break case 7 if %object.vnum% != 53423 set response Do you think we can get new information from %object.shortdesc%?  I doubt it... endif break case 8 if %object.vnum% != 43013 set response Is this a book? endif break case 10 if %object.vnum% != 10325 set response Is this all you could find? endif break default set response Oh, is this a gift for me?  I appreciate it, but I'm fine for now. done done if %response% return 0 mecho %self.name% refuses %object.shortdesc%. wait 2 say %response% endif

rooms.name: Before the Gates of a Stone Building
rooms.description: A crushed gravel path leads away from the great road carved into the ice that lies north and towards a stone building.  Large metal gates with wooden handles block entry into the building, but beyond them is a cheerful light that seems to welcome anyone who comes out this far.  A strange smell, almost reminiscent of rotten eggs, comes from the south and, beyond the building, what looks like clouds of smoke or steam is barely visible.  In any event, the inside of the building must surely be warmer than the chill of this frozen land, so investigating it might not be a bad idea.

North.description: Sirestis' Folly, leading back to the Arctic Village of Ickle, lies to the north.

South.description: Grand gates, made of metal but with wooden handles so the chill of the northern climate won't freeze the hands of anyone who tries to open them, lead into a warmly lit stone building to the south.  Carved into the gates in the Common script is the word "Welcome".

rooms.name: The Coat Room
rooms.description: The gate to the north opens up into this pleasant room.  Benches on either side of the hall provide a place to sit and take off heavy, snow-covered boots and cloaks, and brass hangars are attached to the walls to hold heavy outer garments.  Written on the wall above the passageway to the large room that lies south are the words "Phoenix Feather Resort" in large, blocky letters of the Common script.  A short flight of steps leads there as well, no doubt so that the floors of the building aren't resting directly on the cold ground. Indeed, it is much warmer in here than it is outside, and the light of a fire beckons travelers with the promise of comfort.

North.description: Wind sneaks in from time to time, but the metal gates leading north to Sirestis' Folly and the resort's exit are likely magically enchanted not to let any cold air pass their boundary, since the room stays nice and warm regardless of whether or not they're closed.

South.description: The narrow confines of the coat room open up into a great hall to the south.

rooms.name: The Hearth
rooms.description: Set into the western wall is a massive stone hearth.  Taking up nearly the entire wall, it is constructed of stones collected from everywhere in the world.  Obsidian from Fiery Island, jade from Odaishyozen, granite from the quarries near Toldar's Keep, basalt from Anduin, marble from Nikozia, and even the rare crystals from Technitzitlan can all be found here.  A shelf above the fire holds small sculptures of many styles, and the fire itself has the rich scent of juniper wood.  Cushions scattered on the ground invite people to sit and watch the fire or read by its light, and low tables further encourage sitting on the floor.  Many rugs made from the pelts of local animals keep the floor soft, for it is bare wood underneath.  The great hall lies to the east, and there is a smaller room to the south.

East.description: To the east is the main hall of the resort, which branches out to all other sections including the exit.

South.description: To the south is a parlor with odd-looking chairs and the scent of incense.

extras.text: One sculpture really catches the eye: a purple teardrop shed from a blue eye.  The artist's signature on the piece says "Kourrya 2006".

rooms.name: The Great Hall
rooms.description: Lush, imported carpets cover the pine floorboards in this spacious hall. Comfortable-looking chairs and low tables provide several places to relax and hold conversations, and the walls are hung with paintings and tapestries. Delicious smells come in from the east, where the hall opens up into a dining room.  The crackle of a fire comes from the great hearth to the west, and fresh air sneaks in whenever the gates past the coat room to the north are opened. To the south, a counter detailing the various services the resort offers can be seen.  This particular hall is active even at the strangest hours, whether being utilized by visiting guests or cleaned by the impeccable staff, but it is never too racous.

North.description: Leading out of the building, the smaller hallway to the north ends in a coat room, where travelers can prepare themselves for the frigid temperatures outside without getting in the way of those who just want to relax in the Great Hall.

East.description: The hall narrows a bit, then widens up again into a large dining room set with many tables to the east.

South.description: To the south, a large desk is visible.

West.description: To the west, the warm glow of a large hearth invites a tired traveler to sit down and relax.

rooms.name: The Dining Hall
rooms.description: A large, well-lit hall stretches out here and to the east and south, filled with wide tables and high-backed chairs placed around them in a comfortable arrangement for dining.  The tables are set with fine, white silk tablecoths and beautiful plates from around the world.  Pitchers of sweet water and pots of hot tea are on carts around the room in case a visitor gets thirsty, and delicious smells are coming from the south.  The main hall lies back to the west.

East.description: The dining hall stretches off to the east.

South.description: The dining hall continues to the south.

West.description: To the west, the hall narrows a bit before opening up wider into the main hall of the resort.  Far off, the hearth sheds its inviting glow.

rooms.name: The Dining Hall Overlooking the Cold Hills
rooms.description: Set with many small tables, this section of the dining hall looks like it was designed with smaller parties in mind.  Soft velvet curtains line the glass windows that overlook the hills blanketed in pure, white snow rising to the east.  The chilly-looking, snow-covered view is beautiful, especially when viewed from the comfortable, warm interior of the resort.  A small hearth is set in the south wall, keeping many pots of tea at the perfect drinking temperature.  The only exit is to the west, where the dining hall continues before opening up into the main hall.

East.description: Snow-covered hills begin to rise to the southeast through a set of large glass windows hung with warm-looking velvet curtains.  A birdfeeder set right outside the window is almost constantly visited by hardy songbirds that live up here as well as the rare Northern White Raven.  Small, hardy pine trees line the hills.

West.description: The dining hall continues to the west, where it opens up onto the main hall.

rooms.name: The Massage Parlor
rooms.description: This peaceful room is, unlike the rest of the resort, fully carpeted with a grey shag that muffles the sound of footsteps.  A window on the western wall is bordered by thick white velvet curtains, and the entire room seems to be lit by a white, magical light.  A cushioned table rests in one corner and there are three oddly-shaped chairs, all suitable for relaxing in when being given a massage.  Several folded-up tables and chairs on the south wall suggest that this room can be used as a conference room if necessary.  In the southeastern corner is a large altar made of striped black-and-white marble where incense burns, filling the room with its pleasant smoke.  Yellow light from the north illuminates the room's only exit.

North.description: The great hearth lies to the north.

extras.text: A single flame has been carved into the stone of the altar and embossed with silver.  Below it in tiny Elven runes is the inscription: "Lost, but never forgotten.  Rick Sala 6-21-2006"

rooms.name: The Counter
rooms.description: This spacious, warm extension of the Great Hall leads to a polished wooden counter set near the middle of the room that blocks passage south.  A large sign on the wall lists the various services available for purchase here, and a few chairs line the walls for those who wish to rest and consider before deciding on an activity.  Candles in tall glass casings provide a warm, yellow light, and the skylight lets in the light of moon or sun to help brighten the room as well.  The main hall of the resort is back to the north.

North.description: To the north is the Great Hall.  The carpeted floor between here and there looks like it has seen quite a bit of use.

South.description: A low, swinging wooden gate leads to the south and what looks like a small shop.

extras.text: Hot Springs -    Red Token Massage -        Blue Token Gourmet Meal -   Green Token

rooms.name: The Dining Hall
rooms.description: Brightly colored paintings and tapestries line the walls in this busy section of the dining hall.  Booths set into the wall offer privacy for those who wish to dine here, but a large festival table on the south wall looks big enough to hold even the most populous party.  The light in this room comes from a gorgeous, crystalline chandelier as well as smaller candles set on each table.  The hall stretches out to the north, but a set of swinging doors constantly in use block the way east.

North.description: The dining hall continues to the north.

East.description: A great set of swinging, metal doors lies to the east.  Light and heat and delicious smells come from the other side at all hours of day and night, and a small window is set into the center of each door.  Through the window can be seen the shine of metal and many scurrying figures bent on activity.  It's probably the resort's kitchen.

rooms.name: The Kitchen
rooms.description: Activity surrounds every part of this large, clean kitchen.  Cabinets upon cabinets of supplies, pots and pans, utensils, and more line the walls.  Three different range tops make it possible to work on many different dishes at once, and a bread oven set into the east wall sends out tantalizing scents to tempt travelers.  Though seemingly chaotic, this kitchen is in fact quite orderly - it must be, or it would surely collapse under the weight of all that bustling around.  A set of swinging doors leads back west into the dining hall.

South.description: Through a slight maze of boxes, kitchen tools, and other paraphanelia, a door blends in with the stone walls.

West.description: To the east, a set of large metal double-doors seperates the kitchen from the dining hall.  Windows set in each of the doors give a decent view of diners, wooden tables, and the decorations of the room, though occasionally the windows cloud up due to the humidity in the kitchen.  Their main function is to block the noise of the kitchen from intruding on the peaceful atmosphere of the dining hall.

rooms.name: Women's Dressing Room
rooms.description: Several curtained stalls provide privacy for those who wish to change into bathing outfits (or out of them as the case may be).  A vent of warm air blows down from the ceiling to dry off people and clothing, and tubs of warm and cool water rest along the east wall for anyone wishing to rinse off before entering the hot springs.  A solid pine door blocks intrusion from those of the male persuasion to the east and a crisscrossing wooden barrier lies to the south, obstructing view but not movement.

East.description: A solid pine door leads back to the main hall of the resort, away from the hot springs.

South.description: A crisscrossing series of wooden panels blocks direct vision, but the fresh air coming in from the south suggests that it leads outside to the springs.

rooms.name: Gift Shop
rooms.description: Warm, humid air only occasionally interrupted by a cool draft from the north pervades this spacious room, which lies between the counter to the north and the dressing rooms to the east and west.  Towels, soap, and other bathing accessories are displayed on the walls for purchase in case a prospective customer has forgotten to bring such necessaries to the resort.  The women's room is to the west; its counterpart lies to the east.  Both dressing rooms are blocked by large doors and a twisting hall so that they cannot be intruded.  A few wicker chairs are set in the room in case guests wish to pause before entering or exiting the dressing rooms.

North.description: A low wooden gate at one end of the counter leads out to the Great Hall.

East.description: A large symbol - a circle with a slightly off-center arrow pointing upwards - is followed by the Elven rune for "male", marking this as the door to the men's room.

West.description: The large symbol of a circle atop a cross is followed by the Elven rune for "female", marking this as the door to the women's room.

rooms.name: Men's Dressing Room
rooms.description: Used towels litter the floor in this dressing room, making it rather difficult to navigate.  Curtained stalls line the east wall, for those who wish to have a little privacy while changing, and a full-length mirror is hanging on one of the walls in case anyone needs to inspect their physique before joining the rest of the hot springs.  Tubs of water both warm and cool sit in one corner for anyone who feels the need to rinse off before or after their visit to the mineral springs.  A heavy pine door leading back to the gift shop guards the western wall, and a crisscrossing series of wooden panels prevents vision but not progress to the south, where the pools lie.

South.description: A crisscrossing series of wooden panels blocks direct vision, but the fresh air coming in from the south suggests that it leads outside to the springs.

West.description: A solid pine door leads away from the springs and back into the main hall of the resort.

rooms.name: The Pantry
rooms.description: Cool despite its proximity to the kitchen fires, the pantry is dark and stocked full of supplies both from the north and from far away lands.  Shelves full of vegetables and dried fruits cover the walls and cured meats hang from the ceiling, with grains in bags stacked on the floor.  A niche in the eastern wall looks like it has been dug into the surrounding permafrost, and that is where perishable items like fresh fruits and some vegetables are kept.  Faint scents permeate the cool air, of spices and sweets and other tantalizing tastes.  The kitchen lies through a door to the north.

North.description: To the north, a small door leads out of the quiet pantry and back into the noisy kitchen.

rooms.name: A Private Pool
rooms.description: Chill air feels delightfully cold against the warm waters of the private pool, screened by stone walls on three sides and a wooden panel to the east that blocks view but allows entrance by walking along its twisted path.  Stone ledges in the pool itslef on the north and south edges provide benches for those who wish to sit and relax in the water, and it gets slightly deeper near the middle in case one wants to go for full-body submersion.  Pitchers of cold water are available near the steps leading into the pool so that bathers won't get dehydrated - a common pitfall of hot springs.

East.description: Shallow stone steps lead up to interweaving panels of wood and away from the private spring back up to the wooden walkway.  The panels block vision but allow passage.

rooms.name: A Wooden Walkway
rooms.description: This wooden walkway is warm on bare feet, heated from below by some magic or perhaps some clever use of the area's geothermal heat.  If it weren't, it would soon become quite icy and slick from the steam and the water dripping off guests, but as it is the walkway remains dry.  It is constructed of a dark-hued wood that doesn't seem to come from around here, smoothly lacquered so as to prevent splinters on bare feet.  There is a private pool to the west, and the main pool is through a gate to the south.  North is the women's dressing room. The dressing room and the private pool are both obscured by wooden panels, but the main pool can be seen clearly.

North.description: A mazelike series of panels blocks sight north but allows passage back into the dressing room.  The panels are made of white pine - a soft, yet abundant, wood that emits a slight fragrance.  The steam from the hot springs has left a slight layer of ice on the wood, however.

South.description: A gate made of thin branches of wood leads south.  The branches are spaced enough apart that the shallow steps down to the main hot pool are clearly visible through the slats, and it latches with a wooden mechanism rather than a metal one.  This is likely due to the cold temperatures of the air and the probability of wet hands - freezing one's fingers to a metal gate would be quite unpleasant!

West.description: A series of interweaving wooden panels blocks the view west, but steam billows in from that direction and a sign on the panels reads, in Common, "Private Pool".

rooms.name: A Bubbling Hotspring
rooms.description: It is dangerously hot here at the source of the Phoenix Feather Hot Springs. Still, from time to time the brave, foolish, or pyromantic guests decide they want to experience the pinnacle of heat.  For them, the resort has formed the hot spring into a cozy little pool.  A great cloud of steam rises up as the scalding water touches the chill air, covering the nearby walls of the resort with condensation that sometimes turns to ice and sometimes simply falls back into the pool.  A stone shelf on the north wall, which is the south wall of the resort, holds a pitcher of drinking water so that foolish patrons don't get dehydrated and pass out.  After a guest has reached their limit, they may retreat into the main pool down the cascade to the south.

South.description: Tumbling cheerfully down a series of slightly slippery stones, the hot water goes out from here to the rest of the pool, supplying the resort with the mineral water this place is famous for.

rooms.name: A Wooden Walkway
rooms.description: This railed walkway is set several feet above the ground, for this far north the earth is cold no matter what season it is.  The wooden panels of the walkway are made from a dark, imported wood that has been lacquered to prevent it from letting any splinters into a guest's bare feet.  Magic keeps it warm and dry - or perhaps it is only a clever use of this place's natural geothermal energy.  In any case, it is neither icy nor slippery.  The resort building and the men's dressing room lies to the north, blocked from view by a series of wooden panels, and there is a private pool to the east beyond a similar barrier.  The main pool lies through a gate to the south and down a few steps. There seems to be quite a bit of noise coming from that direction.

North.description: A mazelike series of panels blocks sight north but allows passage back into the dressing room.  The panels are made of white pine - a soft, yet abundant, wood that emits a slight fragrance.  The steam from the hot springs has left a slight layer of ice on the wood, however.

East.description: A series of interweaving wooden panels blocks the view east, but steam billows in from that direction and a sign on the panels reads, in Common, "Private Pool".

South.description: A gate made of thin branches of wood leads south.  The branches are spaced enough apart that the shallow steps down to the main hot pool are clearly visible through the slats, and it latches with a wooden mechanism rather than a metal one.  This is likely due to the cold temperatures of the air and the probability of wet hands - freezing one's fingers to a metal gate would be quite unpleasant!

rooms.name: A Private Pool
rooms.description: A wooden panel blocks view to the west, the southern wall of the resort lies north, and a bamboo divider seperates this private pool from the one to the south, but the eastern view is open, giving a view of the rising hills that stretch from north to south here.  The occasional caribou or camouflaged rabbit can be seen weaving in and out of the pine forests if one stops to look, and occasionally there are glimpses of rarer animals like the arctic fox.  The pool itself is blissfully hot, steaming at all hours of day and night.  Stone ledges around the sides provide places to sit and relax, or the center of the pool is deep enough for full-body immersion.  It is nice and quiet here, perfect for a moment's reflection on the joys of life.

rooms.name: A Steaming Pool
rooms.description: Shallow, grooved wooden stheps lead down from the gate to the north, turning to stone steps about a foot above the water's surface and continuing to the bottom of the pool.  The water is gloriously warm in contrast to the chill air, and the pool here is quite deep.  The bottom is a rough sand, not unpleasant to walk on and surely less prone to accidets than a smooth floor would be.  The water coming in from the east is very hot, but it is both cooler and shallower to the south.  The women's dressing rooms lie to the north through a gate.

North.description: Shallow, grooved wooden steps lead up to a wooden gate with a sign.  The sign has the symbol of a circle atop a cross, and the elven rune for "Female".

East.description: The water coming in from the east is hotter than that circulating in this particular section of the pool, and it looks like it continues for a while in that direction.

South.description: The pool continues south, but gets a little shallower in that direction.

rooms.name: A Very Hot Section of the Steaming Pool
rooms.description: A beautiful cascade of water sends billows of steam down from the north, and the water it adds to the pool is HOT!  Though blissfully theraputic, it's dangerous to stay in water this hot without working your way up to it by spending some time in the cooler sections of the pool first.  Still, for the adventurous, there is no greater thrill than standing right underneath the pounding waterfall.  Rocks have been piled up to direct the force of the water into that one cascade, probably to encourage this kind of behavior.  The pool gets a little deeper, but cooler, to the east and west.  South is a little island to dry off on if the hot water should become too much to bear.

North.description: The scalding waterfall comes down from a steep, yet probably scaleable, series of rocks placed to look like a natural waterfall.  The water for the entire pool looks like it's coming from that direction, so entering the hot spring might not be the brightest idea.

East.description: The pool gets a little bit deeper to the east, but the water isn't quite as scalding hot in that direction.

South.description: To the south is a little sandy island where one could get out of the hot water for a while and cool down.

West.description: The pool is a little deeper and a little cooler - though still quite pleasantly warm!  - to the west.

rooms.name: A Steaming Pool
rooms.description: Ahh, the hot springs at last!  Shallow wooden steps lead down from the northern gate into the pool, becoming stone once they are near, and then under, the water.  The air is chilly and full of steam from the springs, making it hard to see too far.  The smell of sulphur is strong, but one gets acclimated to it after a few minutes.  The water circulating in from the west is very warm.  The pool also continues south, though it is fairly shallow in that direction - perfect for easing one's way in so as not to overheat.

North.description: Shallow, grooved wooden steps lead up to a wooden gate with a sign.  The sign has the symbol of a circle with a slightly off-center arrow pointing upwards and the elven rune for "Male".

South.description: The pool gets a little shallower to the south.

West.description: Hot water seems to be flowing in from the west, where the pool continues for some distance.

rooms.name: A Steaming Pool
rooms.description: Narrow, yet ledged, this place is ideal for semi-private conversation or the simple joys of being nice and warm while all around you it's nice and cold. The surrounding landscape is a light pine forest, usually snowbound but full of gorgeous colors and scents in the summer.  A hush seems to cover the land, and loud noises are swallowed up by the forest.  The pool continues back to the east.

East.description: The pool widens up to the east, and a little ways out there is a sandy island.

rooms.name: A Steaming Pool
rooms.description: This wide section of the hot pool is somewhat shallower than the sections around it, and to the east it breaks free of the water entirely to form a small, sandy island.  The swirling waters move in a general north-south direction, washing away dirt and cares alike, relaxing body and soul.  An isolated arm lies to the west, and the pool continues north and south.  To the south the sound of cascading water is strong.

North.description: The water coming in from the north is slightly warmer, and the pool seems a little deeper in that direction as well.

East.description: To the east is a little sandy island.

South.description: The water flows south into a holding pool for a little waterfall, from which the pool drains out into a river farther south.

West.description: A little arm of the pool stretches off to the west.

rooms.name: The Sandy Island
rooms.description: This little island is set with chairs for those who wish to escape the warm water for a little bit before jumping back in.  The sand is large-grained, so it doesn't stick to wet guests as much as one might think.  This spot also offers a great vantage point for all the different parts of the hot springs, from the gates to the north to the waterfall southwest.  The sand itself is warm, heated by the surrounding waters.  The island deepens into water again in all directions.

North.description: The hottest section of the pool is to the north.

East.description: The pool extends for a ways east, a bit shallower and cooler than the section to the north.

South.description: A secluded pool lies to the south, excellent for those who prefer partial privacy.

West.description: An arm of the pool reaches out to the west, looking a bit shallower than the section to the north.

rooms.name: A Steaming Pool
rooms.description: The hot pool is rather shallow here, its gritty bottom rising towards the small island to the west.  Hot steam rises, ghostlike, but it only provides a slight barrier to sight.  To the east, an isolated arm of the pool gets deeper again, and the gate to the Men's Dressing Room lies a little ways north.  To the south is a lip of the pool, and a view of the serene cold fields that make the water seem warmer by comparison.

North.description: A little deeper and warmer, the pool continues to the north.

East.description: An isolated arm of the hot pool stretches out to the east.

West.description: There's a sandy island to the west that looks like it would be fun to cool off on when the water gets too hot.

rooms.name: A Steaming Pool
rooms.description: The hot springs have been shaped into a small, oval arm here which overlooks the scenery in all directions.  The mass of the resort lies north, shedding its warm glow on the countryside.  A series of mountains rises to the east, eventually turning into the familiar peaks of Nikozia far to the south.  Small hills and pine groves dot the land, verdant in summer but snowbound the rest of the year.  The pool itself is designed for relaxation, with stone ledges on the side to sit on and getting quite deep elsewhere for full submersion.

West.description: The pool continues to the east.  A little ways off, there is a sandy island.

rooms.name: The Steaming Falls
rooms.description: The pool ends here.  A wooden sluice acts as a wall on the southern end of the pool, but the water continues down in a beautiful cascade before joining the creek which heads off to the south.  A set of stairs leads down for those patrons who feel inclined to follow the waters for a little ways.  Billows of steam rise up from the cascade, making it difficult to see exactly what lies along the creek.

North.description: The hot pool continues to the north, where it widens up quite a bit.

Down.description: A gentle cascade leads down into a much cooler-looking creek and away from the resort.  There is a bit of a wooden sluice rigged up to prevent any important items from floating downstream, but it doesn't impede the water too much unless completely blocked.

rooms.name: A Secluded Pool
rooms.description: The ground below slopes down dramatically, leaving this secluded pool on something of a cliff.  Trickles of mineral water flow down the sides of the cliff, forming oddly smooth-looking rivulets.  Far to the south, a creek can be seen winding through the mountains and forests to some unknown destination. The pool itself is deep and has several terraced ledges for sitting, and the sandy island is to the north.

North.description: There's a little sandy island to the north.

rooms.name: A Warm, Icy Stream
rooms.description: Though the creek is shallow, its current begins to pick up a bit here.  The water is warm, even steaming a bit from the hot springs, but near the slower-moving water of the creekside it loses its heat quickly and may even turn into patches of ice.  The water is flowing in from the east and turns sharply to the south as it continues downstream.

East.description: The water flows in from the east, and the resort lies farther upstream.

South.description: The creek continues to the south.

rooms.name: A Warm, Icy Stream
rooms.description: Someone has set rocks into a circle under the falls here, marking the last boundaries of the comfort of the hot springs.  The water is about waist-deep within the circle, though it shallows out quickly as it continues to flow west. As it gets farther away from the resort, the water begins to take on the chill of the northlands, so that here and there are patches of ice along the very edge of the creek.  Stairs cut into the stone lead back up to the resort.

West.description: The stream continues of to the west, each bank covered with eager, green plants that seek the heat of the warm water.

Up.description: A slender wooden sluice stands firmly in the path of the water, but it looks like you could scramble up the rocks on either side of the cascade without much difficulty.  It would be just as much fun to sit under the waterfall, though.

rooms.name: A Warm, Icy Stream
rooms.description: The stream takes another sharp turn here, leading east.  The chill bite of cold air is more apparent here, and there is more ice along the sides of the stream, but the main current is still comfortably warm from the hot springs, though it smells slightly of sulphur.  The resort lies upstream to the north. The creekbed turns again not too far downstream, so it's difficult to tell where exactly it is leading.

North.description: To the northeast, above a small cascade, the lights of a building glimmer. It would be easy to reach it from here by simply heading upstream.

East.description: The stream bends again here, leading to the east.

rooms.name: A Warm, Icy Stream
rooms.description: It's definately getting chillier as the water loses heat this far from its warm source, but it's still fairly comfortable.  Bending again here, the stream is coming in from the west and then heading south.  Chunks of ice occasionally break away from the sides of the creek and flow a little ways in the main current before melting under the heat.

South.description: The stream continues south for a little ways before turning again.

West.description: The water flowing in from the west is quite warm.

rooms.name: A Warm, Icy River
rooms.description: A gorgeous cascade of water from the east adds enough to this little stream that it becomes a little river.  The chilly cascade mingles with the warm flow of the main current, making a little steam to mix with the mist of the waterfall.  As a result, all the surrounding plants and rocks are covered in tiny ice crystals that form when the mist touches them.  It is very beautiful. The stream is passable both north and south.

North.description: The current from the north is not too strong to make headway against, should one wish to continue in that direction.

East.description: Another creek, perhaps a little smaller than the one to the north, find its way to the lip of a cliff here and falls crashing down into the river.  A few large rocks break it up into several small cascades, but it still represents a good amount of water.  It's quite loud, but very pretty.

South.description: The creek goes south for a little ways before bending again.

rooms.name: An Icy River
rooms.description: This river is tough to navigate - it's deep, the current is fast, there are rocks everywhere, and there is barely a trace of warmth left from the hot springs far to the north.  Trees hang along the steep banks of the river, some looking quite strange with trunks going in all directions - probably a result of heavy snows as a sapling.  This chilly river heads downstream to the east and upstream to the north.

North.description: The water flowing in from the north is warmer than one would expect for this climate.

East.description: The river chills off as it heads east.

rooms.name: Icy Rapids
rooms.description: Here at last is the end of the passable section of the icy river.  To the east lie sharp rocks and swift rapids, too many and too dangerous to navigate around.  The water is cold, very cold, and there is ice along its edges where the water moves slowly.  Though the current moves steadily, it is not too strong to swim against.  The only exit is upstream, to the west.

East.description: The ice-filled rapids look much too dangerous to navigate, especially for someone without a canoe.

West.description: It should be possible to continue upstream for some distance, as the water looks much calmer than it does downstream.

rooms.name: A Guest Room at Phoenix Feather Resort
rooms.description: This is one of the rooms that Phoenix Feather Resort rents out to its patrons for a small fee, since many of them travel here to vacation from much farther away than Ickle.  Narrow windows along each wall provide a glimpse of the excellent views without letting too much cold in, though the south window is rather foggy from overlooking the hot springs.  On the east wall is an extension of the main hearth with a happily burning fire lending its warmth to the room.  Set into the wall is a cute little cubby-bed piled high with quilts and pillows that just begs to be napped in.  The staircase leading down isn't very noticeable from below...  For that matter, how does one get into this room in the first place?

Down.description: A discreet staircase leads down t the main hall of the resort.

extras.text: This single bed is set into the wall of the room under the north window. Piled high with handmade quilts and embroidered pillows, it would make a superb reading nook or napping spot.  The colors of the quilts and pillows don't seem to have any pattern to them, as nearly every color imaginable is represented.
